title: Opening Announcements

panelist: Inderjit S. Dhillon, Department of Computer Science, University of Texas at Austin

segmentation: Come to Chicago.
Welcome to KDD 2013.
We have close to 1200.
Attendees are near record breaking, breaking attendance and we're confident that in the next day or so, we'll set a new record.
The way I like to think of KDD is KDD is the fulcrum of big data.
This is the new SIG KDD logo and model KDD bringing together the data mining, data science and analytics communities.
KDD is the only conference.

That spans big data, data mining, data science and analytics, and just as importantly, it's the only conference in this space that includes the algorithms, the foundations, the applications, the practice and the deployment of analytics.
Two logistics.
How many people brought a phone or laptop?
So we we didn't know how many would do that and we care about you.
So what we did is we put a few charging station.
In the exhibits area, how many people drink coffee when they are in Chicago?
OK, for the people who have coffee and need some refreshments, we put refreshments in the exhibits area.
There'll be other refreshment stations during breakfast in the brakes, but starting tomorrow the exhibits open at 8.
There's some charging stations and there's some refreshments, and most importantly, one of the things that makes KDD the fulcrum of big data and data science is sort of the sort of the interesting.
Mixture of people who come here.
We have people from academics from industry and from government and the only place that all those people are together is in the exhibit space.
So go to the exhibit space the there's a new app.
We're trying that some people have said is is really quite useful and I put the you are the app there to sort of help schedule.
I want to go back to that.
First, slide in the upper right hand corner.
We paid one of our conference highly.
One of our highly professional volunteer photographers to take a picture that's right down on the 4th floor of the hotel.
It's on the River walk.
You can walk along the River because a number of years ago the mayor of Chicago, who is a shine retiring person, said that whenever they do new construction along the River.
They have to open up a Riverwalk an after a couple decades.
We have a fascinating Riverwalk and one of the things I urge you to do is to sign up for the architecture tour before or after the after the conference each day.
And you can for about an hour and a half.
You can go along the Ridge.
Varansi Chicago architecture.
So that's a view from this hotel.

It's one of the few.
Examples of what became known as the Chicago Architecture School.
It's on 209 S lasell.
It has a an entrance designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, one of our locals.
It has a two story.
A glass sort of atrium, and it was designed in 80, was built in 87 through 88 by the architectural partnership of Daniel Burnham, an John Wellborn Root.
So there's a picture on the left of Daniel Burnham.
He was he.

He was very involved in the Chicago Exposition and one of the things he reminded us is, you know, in life you could make small plans or big plans, but big plans can inspire in a way that small plans can't less well known.
The firm was called Burnham and Root, and they designed a number of building, some of which are still around.
John Wellborn root.

Tried to summarize some of the things that you'll see this this week.
So we have probably the strongest research track of any conference in this space where you can learn about algorithms, foundations, an emerging applications.
We have multiple research tracks.
You're going here in just a few minutes.
When I stop speaking about the research track we have, which is just important, because this is a cross disciplinary vibrant field.
We have a couple other things that are two other tracks, an one what I'll think of as an emerging track.
Out there, one of them is the industry government track, in which there's, I think some of you were here yesterday, heard Ted Senator and Rogani talk about that.
These are diploid and important emerging applications.
This is, you know, the quality of this track is spectacular.
I urge you to go to that and it's about these applications in industry and government.
Just as important as what I kind of think of as the practice.
Of lot of data mining, data science and big data and we have an industrial practice Expo that does that.
So you know we cover academics.
We cover industry.
We cover government.
One of the things we haven't really done, but there's hints of it in this conference is what you might call data mining data science for the social good, right?
Again, Roghani has.
Started an initiative on that separate from KDD, but those people are here at KDD in one of the.
Such tracks and also in the poster, and I encourage you to go there.
The other thing that we have not traditionally emphasized in this conference, you know most people when they build analytic models, use data.
Those that don't eventually end up in prison, and those that do build good analytic models.
You can't build good analytic models unless you have a good what I call analytic infrastructure.
You have the systems, the applications, the database is an all this stuff that you need to explore data.
Manage data, build, build models and deploy models we have not traditionally, especially compared to other conferences like SIGMOD and Supercomputing.

Some of the other an interop talked about the analytic infrastructure so we took a small step in that direction in in a camp we had on Saturday prior to this where we sort of highlighted that aspect and we hope that will continue and the other you know, probably one of the most interesting things in this Community is the KDD cop an.
You know we had several hundred groups participate in that, and those datasets are one of the artifacts that are left each year with his community.

Because, you know, if you're at at certain companies you have access to large data, but you can generally make that available to others, and so there's this emerging gap for between those who had data and those who did it and the KDD Cup is something we've done in this group to sort of close that gap.
One of the other things we've done, and.

I'm announcing it today is another not for profit called the Open Science Data Cloud has made available about 800 terabytes growing to a petabyte over the next month or two of completely Open Access data that's available to the Community.
But it's hard to move that much data, so one of the things that this not for profit is going to do it, hopefully in some collaboration with this Community is donate about half a million CP.
A core hours so that if you have a meritorious application and you want to analyze a very large data set, you can do it in place in a cloud based infrastructure.

Over this petabyte of Open Access data and the other thing that they're doing, which will be announced in a couple of weeks, which may be relevant to this Community, is there's about 500 terabytes of controlled access, healthcare and genomic data that's going to grow to about 2 1/2 petabytes that's available in the same cloud infrastructure.
That's secure and compliant so that you can.

Compute over that so and we needed a name for that, and I couldn't think of a better name than to call it the root system, because Burnham and Root was so important in the architecture, so that's what's sometimes called data Commons.
That data Commons of a petabyte scale data is available, so you know.
Look around, look at your neighbor.
There are no more excuses with Hadoop with Amazon, with infrastructure with are you can analyze what you want.
You have Open Access data, so think like Burnham think big plans and you know right after this conference, take the data.
Take the infrastructure, take the algorithms and do something that inspires other people.
So I want to turn this over to the program chairs for the research track.
One more thing, welcome an let's let's let's welcome everyone here and have a great time of the next several days.

We have a bit more submissions this year in clustering, but.

And the.

Some lower acceptance also can be observed for feature selection and I don't know the reason, but I do know that when you put other at the subject term for your papers, it's not a very good idea except Entresto is falling to six point, 7% probably hard to match good reviewers.
That's another slice by number of authors, and then that's interesting.
I mean, we have a best paper with only one author, but that's a risky approach in general.
You get if you have only one author for your paper, the acceptance ratio is less than 7% and it is growing linearly with number of authors still reaching 5 authors.
With five authors, you get diminishing returns, and that's on research work.

Until you want to say what's popular this year.
OK, so you see that sort of social media community detection, metric learning and so on have been popular since 2000.
I've.

If you look at the topics that have trended in this year's program, you see there's actually substantial increase in social networks.
And if you look at the trending topics, you see a lot centered around social media Twitter.
And then new and emerging topics like Big Data but also some topics such as bioinformatics and drug discovery seem to be higher than last year.
And if you remember, healthcare was designated and advertised as a main theme.
For this year's Kennedy, so that could be an explanation.

So yesterday we did talk about doing some mining of our own data, so we did look at the keywords from KDD papers published in previous years and you know one reason to do it is because we like doing this stuff and of course we did put it to some use.
So for example, the subject terms that you saw when authors and program committee members.

Made their choices actually came from this mining of past years data and yesterday we saw also that when we chose the program committee we did want to match the kind of papers that we expected to get with enough expertise so and who they gave more details.
Yesterday.
And now let me put up this sort of slide that you can look at and ponder over.
It is let me just explain it.
It's a world map.
The lightly coloured words are from past years, so from 2002 onwards 2003 onwards and the darker colored ones are the most recent.
So you can see that in the earlier KDD years we have topics like visualization and neural networks.
In the mid years we have sort of microarray data Bayesian networks.
And more recently we have a sort of big data cloud computing social, an information networks collaborative filtering Twitter online advertising.
Becoming more and more important.
And if you look at sort of the right.
Corner of this that big Data is an emergent theme.
And that sort of leads me to the first keynote of this conference.
So which is going to be on big Data platform?
And our first keynote is by Doctor Raghu Rama Krishnan, who heads the cloud and Information Services Lab at Microsoft now who is very familiar face at KDD, and he's a recipient of.
The SIG KDD Innovations award I recall first meeting Raghu at the University of Wisconsin at Madison where he was a professor.
And right after I met him, I think he started becoming more involved in companies.
He founded a company called Quick that was.
Question answering company based on sort of cloud computing.
In 2006 he joined Yahoo as a Yahoo Fellow and of course now he's at Microsoft.
So Raghu has worked in a lot of topics that are of interest to carry the audience.
Database management systems, data visualization, scalable clustering.
And now, cloud computing, recommender systems and semantic search.
Like who is the recipient of several awards?
I already mentioned the Security Innovations award.
He also has received the SIGMOD Test of Time, the 10 Year Test of Time Award, a Distinguished Alumnus Award from IIT Madras.
And the very prestigious Packard Fellowship in Science and Engineering.
Rock, who is also an ACM Fellow and an IEEE Fellow, and we're very, very pleased to have him give a talk today.
So without further delay, let me hand it over to the group.
